StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Acenaphthylene was detected in the water from a coal tar contaminated aquifer in St Louis Park, MN(1), collected in 1980, at concentrations ranging from 0.01 to 0.11 mg/kg in the suspended water sediment(2). Wood preserving chemicals at Pensacola, FL were considered to be responsible for an acenaphthylene concentration of 0.05 and 0.03 mg/L at ground water depths of 18 and 24 m, respectively(3). Groundwater samples in 1980 from nearby the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corp disposal site at Love Canal, NY contained acenaphthylene(4). Acenaphthylene was detected in 4 of 46 water samples collected from monitoring wells near gas stations in Rio de Janerio, Brazil at concentrations of <0.01-0.188 ug/L(5).

Reference: (1) Kool HJ et al; Crit Rev Env Control 12: 307-57 (1982)
(2) Fawell JK, Fielding M; Sci Total Environ 47: 317-41 (1985)
(3) Lucas SV; GC/MS Anal of Org in Drinking Water Concentrates and Advanced Treatment Concentrates Vol 1 EPA-600/1-84-020A (NTIS PB85-128239) p. 397 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Acenaphthylene was listed as a contaminant found in drinking water(1,2) for a survey of US cities including Pomona, Escondido, Lake Tahoe and Orange Co, CA and Dallas, Washington, DC, Cincinnati, Philadelphia, Miami, New Orleans, Ottumwa, IA, and Seattle(3).

Reference: (1) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY, p. 94 (2001)
(2) Kveseth K et al; Chemosphere 11: 623-39 (1982)

(5) Chen H-W; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 78: 201-205 (2007)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Eastern Ontario drinking water June to October 1978, 0.1-2.0 ng/L (n=12), Raw water June to October 1978, 0.1-0.5 ng/L (n=2)(1). Two of five samples of Nordic tap water collected in the 1979-1980 time-frame contained acenaphthylene at concentrations of 1.6 to 0.40 ng/L(2). Drinking water sources sampled in Jiangsu Province, China in October 2010 contained acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.7-1.5 ng/L(3). In 2002, three of three drinking water sources in Jiangsu Province, China was found to contain acenaphthylene at concentrations of 0.0015-0.0035 ug/L(4). Household drinking water samples collected in three metropolitan areas of Taiwan in 2005 contained acenaphthylene levels of 110.2, 4.3 and 5.8 ng/L respectively(5).

Reference: (1) Great Lakes Water Quality Board; Report on Great Lakes Water Quality p. 19 (1983)
(2) Staples CA et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 4: 131-42 (1985)
(3) DeLeon I et al; Chemosphere 15(6): 795-805 (1986)

(4) Ohio River Valley water Sanitation Commission; Assessment of Water Quality Conditions Ohio River Mainstream 1978-9 Cincinnati OH (1980) Gustafson KE, Dickhut RM; Environ Toxicol Chem 16: 452-461 (1997)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Acenaphthylene is listed as a contaminant of Great Lakes in Lake Ontario, Erie, Michigan and Superior(1). As of 1985, acenaphthylene had a median concentration less than 10 ug/L and tested positive in 3.0% of 920 ambient waters in the USEPA STORET database(2). Acenaphthylene was detected at 2 of 4 sampling stations along the Mississippi River at an average concentration of 3 ng/L in the summer of 1984(3). Ohio River water contained acenaphthylene at the cities of Wheeling(5). Sampling conducted at four sites of the southern Chesapeake Bay in 1994 found mean acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.291-0.546 and 0.021-0.049 ng/L in the dissolved and particulate phase of the water, respectively(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Acenaphthylene was identified as a stack emission(1) and a component of grate(2) and fly ash(1-3) from municipal waste incinerators. Average acenaphthylene concentrations of 22.4 ug/cu m were detected in coke oven emissions(4). Stack emissions from two medical waste incinerators in Taiwan had acenaphthylene levels of 112 and 11.2 ug/cu m respectively(5). Stack emissions from hot batch mix asphalt plants in Taiwan had an average acenaphthylene level of 12.9 ug/cu m(6). Acenaphthylene was detected in municipal incinerator fly ash emissions(7).

StringWithMarkup.String: Wastewater from the gaseous diffusion plant operated by Union Carbide at Oak Ridge, TN contained acenaphthylene in the volatile fraction(1). Effluent from a sewage treatment facility at Bekkelaget, Norway contained acenaphthylene at concentrations of 37, 471 and 73 ng/L for dry Fall and Spring days, and after a summer rain, respectively(2). Emissions from the pouring, cooling and shakeout of iron castings contained acenaphthylene at an average concentration of 350 and 80 ug/kg for the evaporative casting and green sand processes, respectively(3). Acenaphthylene was detected in the effluent from a textile finishing operation in the southeastern US(4). As of 1985, acenaphthylene had a median concentration of less than 10 ug/L and tested positive in 2.8% of 1,271 industrial discharges in the USEPA STORET database(5). An Oregon state-wide study of compounds in municipal effluents detected acenaphthylene (detection limit 7.7 ng/L) on 5 of 102 samples at a mean concentration 24.6 ng/L(6).

Reference: (1) Snider EH, Manning FS; Environ Int 7: 237-58 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: Sewage sludge collected from six wastewater treatment plants in Beijing, China during 2004-2005 contained acenaphthylene at levels of 21.55-289.86 ug/kg dry weight(1). Sewage sludge collected from six wastewater treatment plants in Korea contained mean and median acenaphthylene levels of 0.107 and 0.017 mg/kg dry wt(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Based on monitoring at a Los Angeles roadway tunnel in 1993, the vapor-phase vehicle emission rate of acenaphthylene was 1949.5 ug/L(1). A 1990-1992 study conducted in Chicago found average acenaphthylene levels of 0.464 and 0.0708 ug/cu m in emissions from diesel and gasoline engines respectively(2). Emissions from outboard marine engine were found to contain acenaphthylene(3). On-road testing of nine heavy-duty diesel vehicles in California detected acenaphthylene emission rates of approximately 0.01-0.04 mg/mile(4). Dynamometer testing of a gasoline-powered automobile and an automobile powered by liquified petroleum gas found mean acenaphthylene emission factors of 76.9 and 14.6 ug/km respectively(5). The emission rate of acenaphthylene from a catalyst-equipped versus non-catalyst-equipped gasoline powered vehicle was 37.0 versus 2180 ug/km(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENTS: Acenaphthylene was detected in sediments collected from Dohkai Bay, Japan in 1974 and 1977(1) and in sediments from the western basin of Lake Ontario in the 1980s(2). Between March 1984 and April 1985, acenaphthylene was detected at trace concentrations in sediments located 0.5 and 1 km from a sewage outfall at the Fraser River Estuary, British Columbia, Canada (3). Sediments collected from Hamilton Harbour and Fawn Lake, Ontario in 1987 contained acenaphthylene concentrations ranging from not detectable (not specified) to 0.839 ug/g wet wt(4). Acenaphthylene comprised roughly 0.5% of the total PAHs detected in sediment samples collected from the Pearl River estuary and adjacent northern South China Sea in July 2002(5). Sediments collected near industrial outflows in the Cochin Backwaters of India in March 2008 had acenaphthylene levels of <5 ug/kg dry weight(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENTS: Acenaphthylene was qualitatively detected in sediment samples collected from nearby the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corp disposal site at Love Canal, NY in 1980(1), in sediments from the southern basin of Lake Michigan in 1978(2), in sediments from the Elizabeth River, VA in the 1980s(3,4) and in sediments from the Black River, OH(5). One of 3 sediment samples from the New York, NY harbor contained acenaphthylene at a concentration of 30 ng/g(6). Acenaphthylene was detected in 2 of 30 samples from Casco Bay, ME in April 1980 at concentrations of 1870 and 165 ppb(7). Acenaphthylene was detected in 1 of 10 sediment samples collected in the mid-1980s from streams feeding Lake Erie within the city of Erie, PA at concentrations of 3261 ug/kg(8). As of 1985, acenaphthylene had a median concentration less than 500.0 ug/kg and tested positive in 6.0% of 359 sediments in the USEPA STORET database(9). Sediments taken from the Arthur Kill, Hackensack and Passaic Rivers, NJ in 1991 had median acenaphthylene levels of 0.48, 0.47 and 0.91 mg/kg respectively(10). Surface sediments collected at 24 offshore sites in southern Lake Michigan detected mean acenaphthylene concentrations of 1.4 ng/g dry wt with a 100% detection frequency(11). Sediments collected from 19 areas of the lower Missouri River in 2002 contained acenaphthylene concentrations of <0.3 to 9.1 ng/g dry wt(12).

Reference: (1) Acheson CM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 23: 245-251 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: Acenaphthylene was detected (concentrations not reported) in 188 soil samples collected in diverse utilization areas of Tianjin, China (farmland, wild land, oil field, urban greenbelt) in the early 2000s(1). Soil sampled at five former manufactured gas plants in France had acenaphthylene levels of 1-172 mg/kg dry soil(2). Farm soils from organically-grown vegetable farms in Eygpt were found to contain mean acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.23 to 4.23 ug/kg dry wt(3). Soil samples taken from 23 sites in Switzerland in 2002 by the Swiss Soil Monitoring Network (NABO) had mean and median acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.6 and 0.5 ug/kg dry wt respectively(4). Soils collected from nine vegetable fields of the Pearl River Delta, South China in 2002 had mean acenaphylthene levels of not detectable (not specified) to 1900 ng/kg(5). The mean acenaphthylene concentration found in nearly 200 rural soil samples collected from around Great Britain was 5.91 ng/g dry wt(6). The mean acenaphthylene level of 182 Japanese paddy soils sampled between 1959-2002 was 4.71 ug/kg dry wt(7). Agricultural soils sampled in eastern Poland had a geometric mean acenaphthylene concentration of 1 ug/kg(8). Acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.2-5.7 ng/g dry wt were detected in sediments taken from the Shinano River, Japan in 2005 and 2006(9).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Atmospheric concentrations of acenaphthylene ranged from 1.0 to 5.3 ng/cu m at New Bedford, MA during Sept 1982 and 1983 sampling(1). Acenaphthylene was quantatively detected in air around Norfolk, VA in the early 1980s(2). During February to April 1984 and 1985, the air of Portland, OR contain acenaphthylene in the gas phase at the average concentration of 32 ng/L and in the particulate phase at an average concentration of 0.021 ng/m3(3,4). The average day and night time concentrations of acenapthylene were 3 and 12 ng/cu m, respectivley, for air in Glendora, CA in August 1986(5). Air samples collected between Nov 1988 and Feb 1989 in Minneapolis, MN and Salt Lake City, UT contained a mean acenaphthylene concentration of 6.9 ng/cu m and a range of 15-166 ng/cu m(6). Acenaphthylene was detected in aerosol particulate samples collected in Kenmore Square, MA in 1994(7). Air monitoring conducted at the Gandy Bridge in Tampa, FL in 2002 detected a acenaphthylene concentration range of 0.0-0.04 ng/cu m(8). Outdoor air samples collected from Fairbanks, Alaska in Feb 2009 had a acenaphthylene concentration of 0.01 mg/cu m(9).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Concentrations of acenaphthylene detected in the ambient air of Kokkola, Finland in 1985 sampling were 32.7, 11.3, 17.6, 38.3, 6.9 and 0.9 ng/cu m(1). Air sampling conducted during summer and winter months in Birmingham, UK detected mean acenaphthylene particulate-phase and gas-phase concentrations of 0.12-0.61 and 2.60-14.79 ng/cu m respectivley(2). Average winter and summer acenaphthylene concentrations monitored at two site in Hong Kong between 1998-2005 were 17.2-27.8 ng/cu m and 14.9-22.5 ng/cu m respectively(3). Atmospheric particulates (PM2.5, PM10) collected in Kozani, Greece contained acenaphthylene levels of 0.21-0.29 ng/cu m(4). Air monitoring conducted at 8 sites in Harbin, China in 2007 reported average annual acenaphthylene concentrations of 1.4-7.1 ng/sample/day(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR AIR: Air monitoring conducted inside of 52 homes along the border between Arizona and Mexico detected acenaphthylene in 15% of all samples(1). Indoor air sampling conducted at 24 homes in Kuwait detected acenaphthylene in 100% of all samples at concentrations of 5-613 pg/cu m(2). Indoor air samples collected from Fairbanks, Alaska in Feb 2009 had a acenaphthylene concentration of 1.0 mg/cu m(3). Monitoring of indoor air at five schools in Kaunas, Lithuania during the 2011/2012 heating season detected acenaphthylene in the particulate matter on the order of 1 ng/cu m(4); however, most of the acenaphthylene detected occurred in the vapor phase(4).

Reference: (1) Halsall CJ et al; Environ Sci Technol 31: 3593-3599 (1997)

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: Monitoring conducted at various sites in the Canadian and Russian Arctic between 1992-1994 detected mean acenaphthylene concentrations of <0.460-41.6 pg/cu m(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: 22 samples of margarines, butter and vegetable oils were tested in Finland; acenaphthylene was detected only in the rapeseed oil sample and at a concentration of 0.07 ug/kg(1). Levels of acenaphthylene detected in olive pomace oil in Spain ranged from 0.43-4.41 ug/kg(2). Maximum acenaphthylene levels (in ng/g wet wt) were detected in the following food items collected in Hong Kong in 2007: coconut milk (5.42), chicken breast (5.71), white wine (1.14), red wine (1.31), edible oils (1.20-2.86), pistachio (2.01), various seeds and nuts (1.24-5.82)(3). Potatoes grown in farm soils at organic vegetable farms in Eygpt were found to contain mean acenaphthylene concentrations of <0.01 to 0.310 ug/kg(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: Bullhead catfish (Ictalurus nebulosus) from the Black River, OH and striped bass (Morone saxatilus) from the Potomac River, MD contained acenaphthylene at concentrations of 270 and 43 ppb, respectively(1). Oysters (Crassotrea virginica) and clams (Rangia cuneata) collected from Lake Pontchartrain, LA in May-June 1980 contained acenaphthylene at average concentrations of 36 and 130 ppb, respectively(2). The compound was tested for but not detected in  Composite fish samples collected from the Great Lakes harbors and tributary mouths between 1980 and 1981(3). It was not decteded in fish samples collected from 13 Lake Michigan tributaries and Grand Traverse Bay sampled in the fall of 1983(4). As of 1985, acenaphthylene had a median concentration of less than 2,000 mg/kg and tested positive in less than 0.5% of 140 biota surveyed in the USEPA STORET database(5). Acenaphthylene levels of 0.07-0.16 ng/g wet tissue were detected in smoked trout originating from Lakes Michigan and Superior(6). An analysis of farmed and wild salmon, collected in 1999-2000, found mean acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.35 and 0.15 ng/g respectively(7). Edible fish taken from the Gornti River, India in 2004-2005 contained a mean acenaphthylene concentration of 1.92 ng/g wet wt with detection in 66.67% of all samples(8).

Reference: (1) Kagi R et al; Intern J Environ Anal Chem 22: 135-53 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: Coral rock oysters (Saccostrea cucculata) collected in Sept 1982 from six locations at Mermaid Sound in NW Australia contained acenaphthylene at concentrations ranging from less than 0.4 to 3 ppb with a 45% frequency of occurrence(1). Metabolites of several 2- and 3-ring aromatic hydrocarbons (AH), such as acenaphthylene, were found in livers of English sole exposed to No 2 fuel oil with concentrations, ranging from 50-1100 ng/g(2). Three analyses of trout from Iceland showed acenaphthylene at an average concentration of 4 ppb(3). Japanese horse mackerel contained acenaphthylene for 3 different methods of preparation at concentrations of 77-392, 160 and 45 ppb(3). Acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.029-0.21 ng/g wet weight were detected in oysters collected from 18 stations in the Yatsushiro Sea, Japan in 2010(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: ENVIRONMENTAL: Milk samples collected from farms in France near potential contamination sources in March 2000 contained mean acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.2-0.8 ng/g milk fat(1). In a nationwide study of milk samples collected from 45 dairy farms in the US in 2000-2001, acenaphthylene was detected at concentrations ranging from below detection limits (40 ng/L) to 828 ng/L with regional mean concentrations of 30.38 to 144.82 ng/L(2). Human milk samples collected from 27 women in Beijing, China in 2005-2006 contained a mean acenaphthylene concentration of 0.132 ng/g fresh weight(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: Acenaphthylene was detected in emissions from open burning of scrap tires of concentrations of 861 and 562 mg/kg of chunk and shred tire respectively(1). Combustion of polystyrene was found to emit gaseous acenaphthylene at a yield of 2.136 mg/g of polystyrene(2). Studies involving the combustion of scrap tires determined acenaphthylene emission rates of 3-250 mg/kg scrap tire(3). Average acenaphthylene emission factors of 0.308-22.08 mg/kg were determined for open burning of various agricultural and forest biomass fuels(4). Weathered bottom ash collected from four Swedish municipal solid waste incinerators in 1996 contained acenaphthylene levels 31-355 ug/kg(5). Testing conducted between 1990-1992 determined average acenaphthylene levels of 1.83 ug/cu m were emitted from wood combustion(6). Acenaphthylene occurs as a coal combustion by-product at emission rates of 14.2 to 1914.5 ug/g of coal depending on combustion temperature(7). Residental wood combustion from fireplaces and stoves had acenaphthene emission rates of 4.97-8.67 mg/kg wood(8). Indoor combustion of biomass for heating and cooking (cotton stalk, wheat straw) was found to emit acenaphthylene at roughly 0.06 fraction of all PAH emissions(9).

Reference: (1) Lee WY et al; Sci Total Environ 159: 185-200 (1995)
(2) Geahchan A et al; J Assoc Off Anal Chem 74: 968-973 (1991)

StringWithMarkup.String: Diesel and gasoline fuels sampled in Taiwan between 1991-1993 contained acenaphthylene concentrations of 1564 and 70-219 mg/L respectively(1). A standard mineral oil sample contained an acenaphthylene concentration of 111.0 ug/10 g mineral oil(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Acenaphthylene has been detected in tobacco smoke and tobacco substitute smoke(1). The amount of acenaphthylene emitted the mainstream smoke from popular brand cigarettes from 14 countries ranged from 79.6-590.5 ng/cigarette(2). Various types of incense were found to have acenaphthylene emission rates of 59.1-604 ng/minute(3). House dust samples collected from homes in Columbus, OH during the heating season of 1992/1993 contained acenaphthylene levels 0.58 ppm(4). House dust samples collected from 75 homes in Ottawa, Canada between Nov 2002 and Mar 2003 had mean and median acenaphthylene concentrations of 0.039 and 0.005 ug/g(5). Bulk atmospheric deposition rates of acenaphthylene at six sites near Rio deJanerio, Brazil during 2003-2004 was 1.3-21.6 ng/sq m/day(6). Mean wet and dry deposition rates of acenaphthylene monitored between May and Nov 2005 in the Venice Lagoon, Italy were 5.7 and 1.6 ng/sq m/day(7).

Reference: Lu H, Zhu L; J Hazard Mater 139 (2): 193-8 (2007)

StringWithMarkup.String: Concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) in tobacco smoke of 12 commercial brand cigarettes were determined in a simulated chamber of 20.25 cu m in size. The total concentrations of 17 PAHs (summation operator PAHs) in the chamber were 3500 and 1152 ng/cu m in vapor phase and particulate phase, respectively. In vapor phase, the yield of naphthalene (NA) appeared to be the most abundant (2462 ng/cig) followed by fluorene (FLUOR) and acenaphthylene (ACY), while the yield of benzo[ghi]perylene (BP) was the most abundant (259.7 ng/cig) in particulate phase followed by phenanthrene (PHEN) and FLUOR. The proportion of PAHs in particulate phase increased with increasing molecular weight. PAHs with two to six rings accounted for 40.2%, 35.3%, 11.7%, 7.6%, 5.2% of summation operator PAHs, respectively. There was no obvious correlation between PAHs, benzo[a]pyrene (BaP) concentrations in tobacco smoke and smoking tar contents, nicotine contents. With the source fingerprint of PAHs in tobacco smoke, NA could be regarded as the marker of tobacco smoke source because of its largest contribution to summation operator PAHs (40.2%), followed by FLUOR (12.7%) and ACY (9.8%). Further study indicated that more than 80% of BaP in indoor air of resident homes in Hangzhou was from tobacco smoke. /Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons/

Section.Description: Potential way(s) in which people may come into contact with a hazardous chemical.  Examples of common exposure routes are inhalation, ingestion, skin/eye contact.

StringWithMarkup.String: Occupational exposure to acenaphthylene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where acenaphylthene is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to acenaphthylene via inhalation of ambient air, inhalation of tobacco smoke, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing acenaphthylene. (SRC)

Reference: (1) Heikkila PR et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 13: 431-7 (1987)
(2) Gammage RB; PAH in Workplace Environ Marcel Dekker Inc p. 653-707 (1983)
(3) Bjorseth A et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 7: 223-32 (1981)
(4) Nordholm L et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 12: 614-8 (1986)

StringWithMarkup.String: Workers at a creosote impregnation plant for lumber were exposed to an average atmospheric concentration of acenaphthylene of less than 0.1 mg/cu m for 18 samples(1). The concentration of acenaphthylene in the personal air at the coal preparation area of a solvent refined coal pilot plant was 13.7 and 3.1 ug/cu m for a welder and an operator, respectively(2). Acenaphthylene was found to be completely in the gaseous phase in the workplace air of an aluminum plant at Soderberg, Norway at an average concentration of 14.74 ug/cu m(3). Acenaphthylene was detected in the workplace air of Danish smokehouses(4).

Reference: Ellenhorn, M.J. and D.G. Barceloux. Medical Toxicology - Diagnosis and Treatment of Human Poisoning. New York, NY: Elsevier Science Publishing Co., Inc. 1988., p. 953

StringWithMarkup.String: Estimates of daily total PAH intake from food (which includes acenaphthylene) vary widely, ranging from a few nanograms to a few micrograms per person(1). The mean dietary intake of acenaphthylene in the United Kingdom (years 1986-1987, 2000) is estimated as 0.13-0.25 ug/day per person(2).

Section.Description: Total amount of a chemical present in an organism at a given time.

(2) Moon HB et al; Chemosphere 86: 485-490 (2012)
(3) Qin YY et al; Environ Sci Technol 45(4): 1630-1637 (2011)
(4) Singh VK et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 54: 348-354 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: Human milk samples collected from 27 women in Beijing, China in 2005-2006 contained a mean acenaphthylene concentration of 0.132 ng/g fresh weight(1); placenta collected from 40 women contained a mean acenaphthylene concentration of 3.06 ng/g fresh weight(1); umbilical cord blood collected from 32 women contained a mean acenaphthylene concentration of 0.350 ng/g fresh weight(1). Adipose tissue collected from Korean women in 2007-2008 contained a mean acenaphthylene concentration of 2.2 ng/g lipid weight(2). Blood plasma collected from 111 human donors in Hong Kong in 2008 contained mean acenaphthylene levels of 93.3 and 38.8 ng/g lipid in females and males respectively(3). Blood samples collected from 56 healthy children (ages 2-12) in Lucknow, India during 2005-2006 had a median acenaphthylene level of 8 ppb(4).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Classification from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Distributed Structure-Searchable Toxicity (DSSTox) database. Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
